did.abstract: University of Michigan professor of law, 1936-1944 and 1968-1972, vice president for university relations, 1944-1951, vice president and dean of faculties, 1951-1962, and executive vice president, 1962-1967. Papers include correspondence and reports concerning University affairs and some course materials from Niehuss' law classes. Included here are files relating to Niehuss' involvement in the University decision to fire three professors investigated by the House Un-American Activities Committee, and in the review of the University's compliance to the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Marvin L. Niehuss and Margaret Niehuss Munchmeyer (Donor no. 4637) in 1968 and 1992. 2000 accession was transferred from the University of Michigan Law School (Donor no. 343).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research with the exception of a folder of material relating to admissions with student identifiable information.
Copyright was transferred to the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Marvin Lemmon Niehuss Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Marvin Lemmon Niehuss was associated with the University of Michigan for over fifty years, starting as an undergraduate in 1920, earning his bachelor's and law degrees in 1925 and 1930 respectively, and eventually serving in a variety of capacities: researcher, law professor, and administrator. His most notable role was legislative relations specialist for the university administration.

Niehuss was born in Lexington, Kentucky and raised in Mississippi. Except for two years practicing law in Chicago during the 1930s, his entire career was devoted to the University of Michigan. He made the move from law professor to administrator during World War II, when he coordinated government contracts for the university as Vice President for University Relations. From 1951 to 1962 he served as Vice President and Dean of Faculties, and from 1962 to 1968, as Executive Vice President.

Among the most pressing issues Niehuss dealt with were enrollment bulges in the late 1940s and 1960s, "cash crises" during the 1950s, and affirmative action issues in the 1960s. He also actively supported the dismissal of three alleged communists on faculty (Professors Nickerson, Davis and Markert) who were questioned by the House Un-American Activities Committee in 1954.
Niehuss retired from administration to resume teaching responsibilities at the Law School in 1968, and was named Professor Emeritus of Law in June 1973. He died in Louisville, KY May 3, 2003

chronitem.event: Vice President and Dean of Faculties

scopecontent.p: The Marvin Niehuss Papers document his career as Law School faculty member and university administrator. The papers include correspondence and reports concerning University affairs and some course materials from Niehuss' law classes. Included here are files relating to Niehuss' involvement in the University decision to fire three professors investigated by the House Un-American Activities Committee, and in the review of the University's compliance to the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

The Niehuss papers have arrived in three separate accessions. Researchers should be aware that there is significant overlap within the three accessions. Specific topics can be tracked across the various accessions. The papers are organized into two series: a small Miscellaneous File, 1945-1951, and Topical Files, 1923-1972.

scopecontent.p: The bulk of the papers (23 linear feet) were accessioned in 1968, and are arranged as topical files, in chronological order by academic year, 1951-1967. These files cover the period Niehuss served as Vice President and Dean of Faculties (1951-1963) and executive Vice President (1962-1968). In addition to the yearly alpha files there are several special files including: Special Advisory Committee to the President on the Cases of Clement Markert, Mark Nickerson, and H. Chandler Davis, 1954; Deanship Search Files; 55 Million Dollar Fundraising Program File; Phoenix Project File; and Sesquicentennial File.

The 1992 accession spans the years 1923-1971, and is arranged as one topical file. Of particular interest are the "Appropriation Requests to the Legislature, 1947-1968," which provide an annual summary of the university's financial needs and goals. Researchers with an interest in the administration's relations with the House Un-American Activities Committee should consult the "American Association of University Professors," "Communism," and "Special Advisory Committee" folders in the 1992 accession; and the 1954 topical files, the folder "The Three" in the 1955-56 topical files, and box 21 in the 1968 accession.

The 2000 accession covers 1929 through 1972, and is arranged as one alphabetical file. Most of the files are topical, and consist of correspondence, reports and background materials on a subject, committee or organization. The accession also contains course outlines, notes and examination questions for two of Niehuss' classes: the Legal Problems of Higher Education seminar, and his Property class. There is also one folder of Personal materials, which includes news clippings, correspondence, and a transcript of a speech given to the Michigan Association of the Professions. Of particular note is the file "Compliance Review" which relates to university compliance issues surrounding the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
